title: SRAM Introduces Lower-Price Maven Base, DB4, and DB6 Brakes
content:
SRAM just added some new more approachable, lower-priced options to some of their mineral-oil brake lineups. The DB4 and DB6 slide in below the existing DB8, while the Maven Base now backs up the Maven Bronze, Maven Silver, and Maven Ultimate. In other news, SRAM also released the entirely new Motive lineup, and we’ve got our first-ride review live now. But while you’re here, let’s cover what’s new in DB and Maven.

DB6 ($95) and DB4 ($75)

Just like the DB8 that launched in 2022, the new SRAM DB6 and DB4 are meant to offer similar power to an entry-level Code brake, but with mineral oil and at a lower price point. The $137 DB8 has an “ambidextrous” lever design and a removable MMX clamp, both of which are nearly ubiquitous across nearly all SRAM brakes. But the DB6 and DB4 are left-right specific, and neither features the removable MMX clamp, instead using a more traditional integrated split clamp.

The integrated clamp on the DB6 brake lever still fits SRAM’s MatchMaker X system that allows you to mount a shifter or dropper lever directly to the brake-lever clamp itself. But to save cost, the DB4 is not compatible with MatchMaker X. Aside from that, the internals of each lever are the same. In fact, despite looking quite different from the DB8, all three brakes will have identical power and on-trail feel, according to SRAM. The caliper architecture is the same across the DB4, DB6, and DB8.

Maven Base ($185)

The Maven Base doesn’t look like much of a departure on the surface. It’s still got an ambidextrous shape, removable MMX clamp, and tool-free reach adjustment as the next-level-up Maven Bronze. It’s even got the same price as the Bronze. But SRAM made some pretty interesting choices. They started by replacing the Swing Link lever linkage with a simpler Direct Link design.

This means there isn’t as steeply progressive of a power curve as you increase your force on the levers. But the goal was to deliver the same braking force for most of the powerband. To achieve this, the Maven Base caliper has four matching 18mm pistons instead of the rest of the Mavens’ 18mm/19.5mm pistons. SRAM claims the Maven Base’s overall power delivery and feel will match other Maven models in most situations, but will not offer quite the same peak power under extremely forceful braking.
